groups.name: Things you wear on your head

easy.notes: Categories: 1) Things with tails — animals and some non-animals with tails. 2) Round objects — general shapes that are circular. 3) Headwear — items worn on the head. 4) Fruits from trees — common fruits. Near-miss temptation avoided: nothing else in the groups shares an obvious tail, circle shape, headwear, or tree fruit connection.

medium.notes: Categories: 1) -er ending words (note: some items like 'teacher' are not literally ending with -er in spelling, but pronounced? Here we use simple suffix recognition; near-miss temptation would be mistaking 'paper' for a person who papers, but it fits as a noun with -er ending). 2) Pairs — items commonly found as bundled pairs. 3) Computer parts — common hardware. 4) Places you sit — seating furniture. Near-miss: 'speaker' could be mistaken as a computer part; it is included in computer parts but also in pairs, so we ensure each item clearly belongs to its group.

groups.name: Words formed by combining two smaller words

hard.notes: Categories: 1) Transportation modes — mix of human-powered and small vehicles; near-miss temptation would be confusing a vehicle with a non-transport item like 'skate' in 'skateboard'. 2) Compound words — common two-word combos; ensure each item is a standard compound (e.g., 'sunflower', 'notebook'); near-miss: 'building' could be a verb or noun but here used as a noun compound. 3) School items — common classroom supplies; 4) Shapes with equal sides — focus on polygons with equal sides. Near-miss: 'circle' is not a polygon; it’s kept separate to avoid overlap.
